ENG097.name: Oral Skills for Foreign Teaching Assistants
ENG097.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG097.description: Practice in English skills for classroom instruction. Pronunciation. Presentations and handling questions. Managing student interactions and classroom situations.

ENG126.name: Introduction to Literary Genres
ENG126.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG126.description: Basics of two or more literary genres such as drama, narrative prose, poetry, or non-fiction, intended for non-majors.

ENG129.name: Introduction to Reading Poetry
ENG129.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG129.description: Basics of reading and interpreting poetry in English, with an emphasis on poetic forms and developing a critical vocabulary. Poetry from a range of time periods and national literatures.

ENG130.name: Film and Society
ENG130.description: Ways of viewing film in its cultural, social, and historical context. Basic critical approaches to film or film genres, focused on a particular topic.

ENG140.name: Literature and Society
ENG140.description: Ways of reading literature in its cultural, social, and historical contexts. Literature in relation to other media and cultural forms. Topics vary.

ENG142.name: Introduction to Popular Literary Genres
ENG142.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
ENG142.description: Popular literary genres such as science fiction, romance, detective novels, gothic, horror, and spy thrillers, including film and other non-print media. Topics vary.

ENG153.name: Introduction to Women Authors
ENG153.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
ENG153.description: Writings by women from various racial, socio-economic and historical backgrounds. Women's choices of subject matter and style. Women's redefinition of literary genres.

ENG200.name: Creative Writing Community
ENG200.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG200.description: Experiential learning course, for students to attend literary events on campus and as outreach within the local community.

ENG204.name: Topics in North American Literatures
ENG204.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG204.description: Selected texts from North American literatures drawn from a variety of historical periods, genres, and cultures, reflecting the diversity of North American experiences.
ENG204.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
ENG204.restrictions: Not open to students in the Department of English or in the English Disciplinary Teaching Minor.

ENG205.name: Topics in British Literatures
ENG205.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG205.description: Selected texts from British literatures drawn from a variety of genres and historical periods, reflecting the diversity of human experiences and the continuity of human concerns.
ENG205.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
ENG205.restrictions: Not open to students in the Department of English or in the English Disciplinary Teaching Minor.

ENG206.name: Topics in Global Literatures
ENG206.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG206.description: Selected texts of various genres from literatures across the globe written in English, reflecting the diversity of human experience.
ENG206.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
ENG206.restrictions: Not open to students in the Department of English or in the English Disciplinary Teaching Minor.

ENG210.name: Foundations of Literary Study I
ENG210.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG210.description: Writing-intensive course in close reading, with substantial attention to poetry, drama, and narrative prose, drawing broadly on texts taken from more than one century and more than one national literature.
ENG210.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
ENG210.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of English or in the English Secondary Teaching Major or in English Elementary Teaching Major or in English Disciplinary Teaching Minor and open to students in the Language Arts Elementary Teaching Major.

ENG211H.name: Honors Foundation in Literary Studies
ENG211H.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG211H.description: Literary form and close reading. Substantial attention to poetry, drama, and narrative prose, drawing broadly on texts taken from more than one century and more than one national literature.
ENG211H.restrictions: Open to students in the Honors College or approval of department.

ENG218.name: Introduction to Shakespeare
ENG218.description: Selected plays from different periods and genres of Shakespeare's career.
ENG218.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
ENG218.restrictions: Not open to students in the Department of English.

ENG223.name: Introduction to Creative Non-Fiction Writing
ENG223.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG223.description: Directed practice in the writing of creative non-fiction. Types and structures available to the creative non-fiction writer.

ENG226.name: Introduction to Creative Writing
ENG226.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG226.description: Introduction to major forms and methods of creative writing
ENG226.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

ENG227.name: Introduction to Playwriting
ENG227.description: Basic elements of playwriting through writing and critical analysis of original scenes, one-act plays and analysis of dramatic technique in selected works by professional playwrights.

ENG228.name: Introduction to Fiction Writing
ENG228.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG228.description: Directed practice in the writing of fiction. Types and structures available to the fiction writer.

ENG229.name: Introduction to Poetry Writing
ENG229.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG229.description: Directed practice in the writing of poetry. Types and structures available to the poetry writer.

ENG231.name: Film and Literature
ENG231.description: Differences and similarities between filmic texts and literary texts and between viewing and reading. The process of adaptation from literature to film.
ENG231.prerequisite: (FLM 230 or ENG 210) or completion of Tier I writing requirement
ENG231.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

ENG232.name: Writing as Exploration
ENG232.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG232.description: Writing and study of non-fiction prose that reflects on experience, individual and social. Topics vary.
ENG232.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I writing requirement.
ENG232.restrictions: Not open to students in the Department of English.

ENG280.name: Foundations of Literary Study II
ENG280.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG280.description: Literary and critical theory. How literature is constituted and how representation works. Assumptions behind and limits of a range of theoretical approaches. Application of theory to literary texts.
ENG280.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the Department of English.

ENG290.name: Independent Study
ENG290.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG290.description: Special projects arranged by an individual student and a faculty member in areas supplementing regular course offerings.

ENG302.name: Introduction to English Language Studies
ENG302.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG302.description: Acquisition of oral and written English. English dialects and styles. Minority dialects and Standard English. Reading and writing English.
ENG302.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
ENG302.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the English Major or in the English Secondary Teaching Major or in English Disciplinary Teaching Minor or in Language Arts Elementary Teaching Major.

ENG308.name: Readings in Literature for Young Adults
ENG308.description: Extensive readings across a range of genres of literature for young adults, including realistic and historical fiction, fantasy, myth and legend.
ENG308.restrictions: Open to students in the English Secondary Teaching Major or in the English Disciplinary Teaching Minor.

ENG314.name: Readings In North American Literatures
ENG314.description: Extensive readings of texts by North American writers across genres, historical periods, and/or regions.
ENG314.prerequisite: {Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement} or (ENG 210 or ENG 211H)

ENG315.name: Readings in British Literatures
ENG315.description: Extensive readings of texts from the British Isles and Empire, selected across genres, historical periods, and/or regions.
ENG315.prerequisite: {Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement} or (ENG 210 or ENG 211H)

ENG316.name: Readings in Irish Literature and Culture
ENG316.semester: Spring of every year, Summer of every year
ENG316.description: Extensive readings of texts by Irish writers selected across genres, periods, and/or regions.
ENG316.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

ENG318.name: Readings in Shakespeare
ENG318.description: Extensive readings in Shakespeare’s works across genres, considered in relation to historical, cultural, and performance contexts.
ENG318.prerequisite: {(ENG 126 or ENG 129 or ENG 140 or ENG 142 or ENG 153 or ENG 204 or ENG 205 or ENG 206 or ENG 218) and Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement} or (ENG 210 or ENG 211H)

ENG319.name: Readings in Michigan Literature
ENG319.description: Extensive readings of texts by Michigan writers across genres, historical periods, media, and/or different regions of the state.
ENG319.prerequisite: {Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement} or (ENG 210 or ENG 211H)

ENG320A.name: Methodologies of Literary History: Genre
ENG320A.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG320A.description: Examination of literary works in relation to historical change, seen through the lens of genre. Reflection on the theories and practices of literary history.
ENG320A.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the Department of English or in the English Elementary Teaching Major or in the English Disciplinary Teaching Minor or in the Language Arts Elementary Teaching Major or in Language Arts Disciplinary Teaching Minor.

ENG320B.name: Methodologies of Literary History: Region, School, or Movement
ENG320B.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG320B.description: Examination of literary works in relation to historical change, seen through the lens of geographical networks and/or aesthetic alliances. Reflection on the theories and practices of literary history.
ENG320B.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of English or in the English Elementary Teaching Major or in the English Disciplinary Teaching Minor or in the Language Arts Elementary Teaching Major or in Language Arts Disciplinary Teaching Minor.

ENG320C.name: Methodologies of Literary History: Canon Formation
ENG320C.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG320C.description: Examination of literary works in relation to historical change, through the lens of why canons form, or debates over canonical inclusion. Reflection on the theories and practices of literary history.
ENG320C.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the Department of English or in the English Elementary Teaching Major or in English Disciplinary Teaching Minor.

ENG320D.name: Methodologies of Literary History: History and Theory of Creative Writing
ENG320D.description: Reflection on the theories and practices of literary history, as seen through the specific lens of creative writing.
ENG320D.prerequisite: (ENG 210 or ENG 211H) and (ENG 223 or ENG 226 or ENG 228 or ENG 229 or ENG 227)
ENG320D.restrictions: Open to students in the English Major.

ENG323.name: Readings in Non-Fiction
ENG323.description: Extensive reading in major forms of literary nonfiction in English.
ENG323.prerequisite: {Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement} or (ENG 210 or ENG 211H)

ENG324.name: Readings in Epic
ENG324.description: Extensive reading of works in the ancient, medieval and/or early modern epic traditions. Forms of epic as produced within specific social and historical circumstances.
ENG324.prerequisite: {Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement} or (ENG 210 or ENG 211H)

ENG325.name: Readings in Graphic Narrative
ENG325.description: Extensive Readings of graphic narratives across genres, historical periods, and/or print cultures and national traditions
ENG325.prerequisite: {Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement} or (ENG 210 or ENG 211H)

ENG326.name: Readings in Drama and Performance Studies
ENG326.description: Extensive readings in drama from a range of centuries and traditions. Focus on a range of dramatic forms and cultural expression through performance, and specific social or historical circumstances.
ENG326.prerequisite: {Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement} or (ENG 210 or ENG 211H)

ENG328.name: Readings in Novel and Narrative
ENG328.description: Extensive readings in the novel from a range of centuries and traditions. Forms of the novel and narrative aesthetics within specific social and historical circumstances.
ENG328.prerequisite: {Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement} or (ENG 210 or ENG 211H)

ENG329.name: Readings in Poetry and Poetics
ENG329.description: Extensive reading in poetry in English from a range of centuries and traditions. Forms of poetry within specific social and historical circumstances. Aesthetics of language and fundamentals of poetics.
ENG329.prerequisite: {Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement} or (ENG 129 or ENG 210 or ENG 211H)

ENG334.name: Introduction to Screenwriting (W)
ENG334.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG334.description: Basic elements of screenwriting. Dramatic action, exposition, plotting, characterization and dialogue, finalizing and marketing the script.
ENG334.prerequisite: (FLM 230 or concurrently) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

ENG340.name: Theory and Methods of Popular Culture Studies
ENG340.description: Examination of the theories and methods of studies in popular culture.
ENG340.prerequisite: ((ENG 142) and completion of Tier I writing requirement) or ((ENG 320A or concurrently) or (ENG 320B or concurrently) or (ENG 320C or concurrently))

ENG342.name: Readings in Popular Literary Genres
ENG342.description: Extensive reading within a particular genre of popular literature such as science fiction, crime fiction or Gothic, with possible attention to media other than print.
ENG342.prerequisite: {Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement} or (ENG 142 or ENG 210 or ENG 211H)

ENG350.name: Readings in African, African-American, or African Diaspora Literature
ENG350.description: Extensive readings in multiple genres drawn from the literature of Anglophone Africa, from African American writers, or from the African Diaspora.
ENG350.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

ENG351.name: Readings in Chicano and Latino Literatures
ENG351.description: Extensive readings in American multiethnic literatures. Focus on the syncretic experience of early and recent immigrants.
ENG351.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I writing requirement.

ENG352.name: Readings in Asian/Asian American/Asian Diaspora Literature and Visual Culture
ENG352.description: Extensive reading of texts by Americans of Asian descent or by Asians in English or English translation. Attention to artistic, historical, and cultural contexts.
ENG352.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

ENG353.name: Readings in Women Writers
ENG353.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG353.description: Extensive reading in texts by women, focused within a particular national tradition or period or within a particular genre. Critical responses to these texts. Feminist approaches to literature.
ENG353.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

ENG354.name: Readings in Native American Literature
ENG354.description: Extensive reading in Native American fiction, essays, and poetry, from early 19th century writings to contemporary works.
ENG354.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I writing requirement.

ENG355.name: Readings in Sexuality and Literature
ENG355.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG355.description: Extensive reading in literature drawing on gay, lesbian, bisexual, transgender, and/or queer perspectives.
ENG355.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

ENG356.name: Readings in Jewish Literature
ENG356.description: Extensive readings in a range of genres by Jewish writers, including fiction, poetry, drama, memoir, and/or film. Cultural and artistic contexts of Jewish literature.
ENG356.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

ENG360.name: Studies in Postcolonial and Diaspora Literature (W)
ENG360.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG360.description: Extensive reading and research in literatures of colonialism, decolonization, neocolonialism, cultural and political independence. Texts from Asia, Africa, the Caribbean, Latin America and/or various diaspora communities.
ENG360.prerequisite: (ENG 280) and ((ENG 320A or concurrently) or (ENG 320B or concurrently) or (ENG 320C or concurrently)) and Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
ENG360.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of English or in the English Disciplinary Teaching Minor.

ENG362.name: Studies in Modern/Contemporary Literature (W)
ENG362.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG362.description: Extensive readings and research in modernist, postmodernist, and recent literary texts from multiple genres and national traditions.
ENG362.prerequisite: (ENG 280) and ((ENG 320A or concurrently) or (ENG 320B or concurrently) or (ENG 320C or concurrently)) and Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
ENG362.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of English or in the English Disciplinary Teaching Minor.

ENG364.name: Studies in 18th-/19th-Century Literature (W)
ENG364.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG364.description: Extensive reading and research in literary texts in English in multiple genres. Focused on one or more periods from 1660 through 1914.
ENG364.prerequisite: (ENG 280) and ((ENG 320A or concurrently) or (ENG 320B or concurrently) or (ENG 320C or concurrently)) and Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
ENG364.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of English or in the English Disciplinary Teaching Minor.

ENG368.name: Studies in Medieval/Early Modern Literature (W)
ENG368.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG368.description: Extensive reading and research in literary texts in English in multiple genres. Focused on one or more periods from ca. 650 to 1660.
ENG368.prerequisite: (ENG 280) and ((ENG 320A or concurrently) or (ENG 320B or concurrently) or (ENG 320C or concurrently)) and Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
ENG368.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of English or in the English Disciplinary Teaching Minor.

ENG391.name: Special Topics in English
ENG391.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG391.description: Special topics supplementing regular course offerings proposed by faculty on a group study basis.
ENG391.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

ENG392.name: Special Topics in English: Creative Writing
ENG392.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG392.description: Special topics supplementing regular course offerings proposed by faculty on a group study basis.
ENG392.prerequisite: (ENG 210 or ENG 211H) and (ENG 223 or ENG 226 or ENG 227 or ENG 229)

ENG394.name: Popular Culture Experience
ENG394.description: Experiential learning in popular culture studies through cooperative activities with a cultural organization, investigating community through a creative process, and /or working closely with a community organization dedicated to a specific cultural project
ENG394.prerequisite: (ENG 340 or ENG 342) and completion of Tier I writing requirement
ENG394.restrictions: Not open to freshmen and open to undergraduate students in the English Major.

ENG395.name: Writing Center Theory and Practice
ENG395.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG395.description: Writing center theory and practice. Consulting practices.
ENG395.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

ENG400.name: Writing Intensive Unit
ENG400.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG400.description: Special writing projects by arrangement, appended to another concurrently enrolled 400-level English literary or film studies course.
ENG400.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Department of English or in the English Disciplinary Teaching Minor. Approval of department; application required.

ENG406.name: Topics in English Language Studies
ENG406.description: Focus on a major issue in the study of English, such as language planning in the United States, the making and use of dictionaries, and gender and language in English.
ENG406.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I writing requirement.
ENG406.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

ENG408.name: Critical Literacies and Communities
ENG408.description: Literacies as sociocultural processes and their function in classrooms and communities. Focus on critical literacy theories and research, education justice, ethical solidarity with students and communities, and pedagogical applications for educators
ENG408.prerequisite: (ENG 302) and completion of Tier I writing requirement
ENG408.restrictions: Open to sophomores or juniors or seniors in the Department of English or in the English Secondary Teaching Major.

ENG413.name: Critical Questions in Language and Composition (W)
ENG413.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG413.description: Intensive writing workshop with focus on writing theory and research, writing in response to literature, and the writing process.
ENG413.prerequisite: ENG 302 and Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
ENG413.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the English Secondary Teaching Major and open to juniors or seniors in the English Disciplinary Teaching Minor.

ENG420.name: Language and Culture
ENG420.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG420.description: Domain, issues, and methods of cultural linguistics. Relationship between language and culture. Language and ethnicity, status, and role. Pidgin and Creole languages. Crosscultural communication.
ENG420.prerequisite: (ENG 302 or ANP 201 or ANP 320 or LIN 200 or LIN 401) and Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

ENG422.name: Seminar in Genre and Form
ENG422.description: Advanced analysis in the history and practice of genre and form. Critical and theoretical approaches to a specific genre. Experimentation and the limits of genre. Topics vary.
ENG422.prerequisite: ENG 360 or ENG 362 or ENG 364 or ENG 368
ENG422.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of English.

ENG423.name: Advanced Creative Non-Fiction Writing
ENG423.description: Directed practice in creative non-fiction writing at the advanced level, including analysis of texts and writing exercises.
ENG423.prerequisite: (ENG 223 or ENG 226) and (ENG 227 or ENG 228 or ENG 229 or FLM 334)

ENG426.name: Seminar in Drama or Performance Studies
ENG426.description: Advanced analysis in American, British, Continental European or World drama or in performance studies. Topics vary.
ENG426.prerequisite: (ENG 360 or ENG 362 or ENG 364 or ENG 368) or (ENG 326 and completion of Tier I writing requirement)
ENG426.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Department of English or in the Theatre major or in the English Disciplinary Teaching Minor.

ENG428.name: Advanced Fiction Writing
ENG428.description: Advanced workshop in writing short stories and longer forms of fiction. Reading and analysis of published fiction.
ENG428.prerequisite: (ENG 228 or ENG 226) and (ENG 223 or ENG 227 or ENG 229 or FLM 334)

ENG429.name: Advanced Poetry Writing
ENG429.description: Advanced workshop in writing original poems, reading contemporary poetry; issues of craft and poetics.
ENG429.prerequisite: (ENG 229 or ENG 226) and (ENG 223 or ENG 227 or ENG 228 or FLM 334)

ENG434.name: Advanced Screenwriting (W)
ENG434.description: Advanced workshop in writing screenplays. Reading and analysis of published screenplays. Attention to film production.
ENG434.prerequisite: (FLM 334 or approval of department) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

ENG440.name: Seminar in Popular Culture Studies
ENG440.description: Advanced topics in theories and subjects of popular culture studies. Popular Culture’s intersection with theories of the other arts and media, politics, and identity.

ENG441.name: Seminar in Early American Literature
ENG441.description: Advanced analysis of major themes and developments in American writing before 1820 to illustrate the diversity of voices and texts generated in and about America from first contact to the end of the early republic. Topics vary.
ENG441.prerequisite: ENG 360 or ENG 362 or ENG 364 or ENG 368
ENG441.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Department of English.

ENG443.name: Seminar in 19th Century American Literature
ENG443.description: Advanced analysis in the major themes and developments in literary culture in the United States from the establishment of the Republic to the turn of the last century. Topics vary.
ENG443.prerequisite: ENG 360 or ENG 362 or ENG 364 or ENG 368
ENG443.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Department of English.

ENG445.name: Seminar in 20th and 21st Century American Literature
ENG445.description: Advanced analysis in literary culture in the United States from the modern and contemporary eras. Topics vary.
ENG445.prerequisite: ENG 360 or ENG 362 or ENG 364 or ENG 368
ENG445.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Department of English.

ENG448.name: Seminar in Gender and Literature
ENG448.description: Advanced analysis in literary works within the context of sexual differences or sexuality studies. May include women writers, feminism, masculinity studies, gay, lesbian, or transgender studies. Topics vary.
ENG448.prerequisite: (ENG 360 or ENG 362 or ENG 364 or ENG 368) or (WS 202 or WS 304 or approval of department)
ENG448.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Department of English or in the Women, Gender and Social Justice Specialization or approval of department.

ENG449.name: Seminar in Race, Ethnicity, and Literature
ENG449.description: Advanced analysis in world literatures which reflect upon the contested categories of race, ethnicity, and culture, their histories, conceptualizations, global diffusion, and trajectories. Post-race identity formations. Topics vary.
ENG449.prerequisite: ENG 360 or ENG 362 or ENG 364 or ENG 368
ENG449.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Department of English or in the African American & African Studies Specialization or in the Chicano/Latino Studies Specialization.

ENG450.name: Seminar in African American Literature
ENG450.description: Advanced analysis of a single writer, group of writers, period, or genre in the field of African American literature. Critical reception, cultural production, or cultural criticism. Topics vary.
ENG450.prerequisite: ENG 360 or ENG 362 or ENG 364 or ENG 368 or approval of department
ENG450.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Department of English or in the African American and African Studies Specialization.

ENG452.name: Seminar in 20th and 21st Century British Literature
ENG452.description: Advanced analysis in literary culture of Britain, Ireland, and other countries influenced by England, exclusive of the United States, from the modern and contemporary eras. Topics vary.
ENG452.prerequisite: ENG 360 or ENG 362 or ENG 364 or ENG 368
ENG452.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Department of English.

ENG454.name: Seminar in Medieval Literature and Culture
ENG454.description: Advanced analysis in texts and cultural contexts of late medieval Britain. Chaucer, Langland, the Gawain-poet, Arthurian romance, mystical writers, drama. Some selections in Middle English. Topics vary.
ENG454.prerequisite: ENG 360 or ENG 362 or ENG 364 or ENG 368
ENG454.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Department of English.

ENG455.name: Seminar in Early Modern Literature
ENG455.description: Advanced analysis in key authors, texts, and cultural contexts of the 16th - 17th centuries, grounded in recent critical questions and early modern social issues; Topics vary.
ENG455.prerequisite: ENG 360 or ENG 362 or ENG 364 or ENG 368
ENG455.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the English major.

ENG457.name: Seminar in 18th-Century British Literature
ENG457.description: Advanced analysis in British writing from 1660-1837, considering issues such as decline of the epic, emergence of satire, rise of the novel, romanticism, and revolutionary discourse. Topics vary.
ENG457.prerequisite: ENG 360 or ENG 362 or ENG 364 or ENG 368
ENG457.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Department of English.

ENG458.name: Seminar in 19th-Century British Literature
ENG458.description: Advanced analysis in British texts, culture and society from 1789-1914, considering issues such as the development of empire, scientific culture, revolution, nationalism, the woman question, aestheticism. Topics vary.
ENG458.prerequisite: ENG 360 or ENG 362 or ENG 364 or ENG 368
ENG458.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Department of English.

ENG460.name: Seminar in Global and Postcolonial Literature
ENG460.description: Advanced analysis in textual cultures of colonial/postcolonial societies. Theories of colonial discourse, postcolonialism, globalization. Literary or visual materials from Africa, Latin America, Asia, or diaspora. Topics vary.
ENG460.prerequisite: ENG 360 or ENG 362 or ENG 364 or ENG 368 or approval of department
ENG460.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the College of Arts and Letters and open to juniors or seniors in the College of Social Science.

ENG462.name: Seminar in Transatlantic Literature
ENG462.description: Advanced analysis in the formation of modern literature within a transatlantic zone of cultural transfer, displacement, and movement, from the seventeenth century to the present. Topics vary.
ENG462.prerequisite: ENG 360 or ENG 362 or ENG 364 or ENG 368 or approval of department
ENG462.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the College of Arts and Letters or in the Department of English or in the Interdisciplinary Humanities major.

ENG466.name: Seminar in Literatures of the Pacific Rim
ENG466.description: Advanced analysis in Transpacific texts and cultures, confluences and clashes, including movement between America and Asia, or within each region itself. Topics vary.
ENG466.prerequisite: ENG 360 or ENG 362 or ENG 364 or ENG 368 or approval of department
ENG466.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the College of Arts and Letters.

ENG473A.name: Literature and Medicine
ENG473A.description: Human dimensions of medicine as seen in literature. Health, illness, mortality. Medical dilemmas. Physical and psychological self. Psychological theories used in interpreting literature. Cultural history of the body. Theories of embodiment.
ENG473A.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
ENG473A.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

ENG473B.name: Law and Literature
ENG473B.description: Literature about law and legal institutions. Literary and legal theories of textual interpretation. The relation of law and legal institutions to conceptions of justice as presented in literature and in philosophical and cultural studies.
ENG473B.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
ENG473B.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

ENG475.name: History of the Book: From Manuscripts to Comics
ENG475.description: History of the book from medieval manuscripts to modern forms. Publishing, illustration, censorship, manuscript and print culture.

ENG478A.name: Literature, Technology, and Representation
ENG478A.description: Literature in relationship to technological innovations and theories of signification and dissemination. How literature represents technology. New modes of media and their impact on literary forms.
ENG478A.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
ENG478A.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

ENG478B.name: Literature and Visual Culture
ENG478B.description: Literature in relationship to theories of representation and the visual arts, which may include photography, film, painting, theater, graphic novels, and architecture.
ENG478B.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
ENG478B.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

ENG480.name: History of Western Literary Criticism
ENG480.description: Sources of the practice and theory of literary criticism in the West including the development of modern critical values in the work of Dryden, Johnson, Coleridge, Arnold, Eliot. Cambridge English, American New Criticism. Poststructuralism and oppositional practices.
ENG480.prerequisite: (ENG 210) and completion of Tier I writing requirement.
ENG480.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

ENG481.name: Seminar in Critical and Cultural Theory
ENG481.description: Advanced analysis in theoretical approaches to textual studies, selected from perspectives such as formalist, narrative, hermeneutical, semiotic, Marxian, psychoanalytic, poststructuralist, postcolonial, and/or other recent critical discourses.
ENG481.prerequisite: (ENG 280 or approval of department) and completion of Tier I writing requirement
ENG481.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

ENG482.name: Seminar in Feminist Literary and Cultural Theory
ENG482.description: Advanced analysis in feminist literary, critical, and cultural theory and its implications for reading and studying literature.
ENG482.prerequisite: (ENG 280 or ENG 353 or ENG 448 or WS 202) and completion of Tier I writing requirement
ENG482.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Department of English or in the Women's and Gender Studies Minor.

ENG484B.name: Critical Questions in Region, School, Movement
ENG484B.description: Intensive study of literary networks connected through geography and/or aesthetics. Writing that integrates archival, primary, or secondary sources and contributing to discussion in the field.
ENG484B.prerequisite: ENG 360 or ENG 362 or ENG 364 or ENG 368
ENG484B.restrictions: Open to seniors in the Department of English.

ENG484C.name: Critical Questions in a Literary Period
ENG484C.description: Intensive study of current issues in a particular literary period. Writing that integrates archival, primary, or secondary sources and contributing to discussion in the field.
ENG484C.prerequisite: ENG 360 or ENG 362 or ENG 364 or ENG 368
ENG484C.restrictions: Open to seniors in the Department of English.

ENG484D.name: Critical Questions in a National Literature
ENG484D.description: Intensive study of current issues situated within the literature of a particular nation. Writing that integrates archival, primary, or secondary sources and contributing to discussion in the field.
ENG484D.prerequisite: ENG 360 or ENG 362 or ENG 364 or ENG 368
ENG484D.restrictions: Open to seniors in the Department of English.

ENG489H.name: Senior Honors Independent Project
ENG489H.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG489H.description: A substantial critical essay, a comparable essay arising from an internship, equivalent creative writing, or a similar project. Writing supervised by a faculty adviser.
ENG489H.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I writing requirement.
ENG489H.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Department of English or approval of department.

ENG490.name: Independent Study
ENG490.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG490.description: Special projects arranged by an individual student and a faculty member in areas supplementing regular course offerings.
ENG490.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
ENG490.restrictions: Not open to sophomores and not open to freshmen. Approval of department.

ENG492.name: Seminar in English
ENG492.description: Specific topic in the language, literatures, or discursive practices of English. Emphasis on individual and group research and on the discussion of student papers.
ENG492.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I writing requirement.
ENG492.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Department of English or in the English Major.

ENG492H.name: Honors Seminar in English
ENG492H.description: Specific topic in the language, literatures, or discursive practices of English. Individual and group research. Discussion of student papers.
ENG492H.restrictions: Open to students in the Honors College and open to seniors in the Department of English or approval of department.

ENG493.name: English Internship
ENG493.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG493.description: Supervised pre-professional field experience in English.
ENG493.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
ENG493.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Department of English or in the English Major.

ENG499.name: Senior Thesis Research (W)
ENG499.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG499.description: Faculty-supervised research project that demonstrates ability to do independent research and submit or present a major paper.
ENG499.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
ENG499.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the English Major. Approval of department.

ENG802.name: Literary Criticism and Theory
ENG802.description: Critical thinking from Plato and Aristotle to postmodern theory. Deep contexts of current critical practice.
ENG802.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the College of Arts and Letters or approval of department.

ENG813.name: Literatures in English before 1800
ENG813.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG813.description: Broad reading in Anglophone writing before 1800. Assimilating and synthesizing the texts that compose a field of inquiry.
ENG813.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the College of Arts and Letters or approval of department.

ENG814.name: Literatures in English after 1800
ENG814.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG814.description: Broad reading in Anglophone writing after 1800. Assimilating and synthesizing the texts that compose a field of inquiry.
ENG814.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the College of Arts and Letters or approval of department.

ENG818.name: Studies in Genre and Media
ENG818.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG818.description: Verbal and visual genres and media. Film, visual culture, and literary genres.
ENG818.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the College of Arts and Letters or approval of department.

ENG819.name: Special Topics in Language and Literature
ENG819.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG819.description: Reading course organized around a broad theme, a critical question, a national literature or the work of a single author.
ENG819.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the College of Arts and Letters or approval of department.

ENG820.name: Professionalization Seminar
ENG820.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG820.description: Seminar constructed around the doctoral emphases that focuses on a specific critical problem resulting in significant preparation for the comprehensive examination.
ENG820.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of English or in the English Major or approval of department.

ENG821.name: Proseminar in Comparative Literature
ENG821.description: History and practice of comparative literature including foundational concepts and current directions.
ENG821.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the College of Arts and Letters.

ENG823.name: Seminar in Comparative Literary Criticism
ENG823.description: Theory and practice of comparative literary criticism, with attention to the development of critical approaches and to current topics in the critical literature.
ENG823.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the College of Arts and Letters.

ENG826.name: Special Topics Seminar
ENG826.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENG826.description: Seminar constructed around a topic and critical problem outside the doctoral emphases.
ENG826.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of English or approval of department.

ENG841.name: Topics in the Teaching of English
ENG841.description: Selected topics and issues in the teaching of English and the language arts.
ENG841.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the College of Arts and Letters or College of Education or approval of department.

ENG890.name: Independent Study
ENG890.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
ENG890.description: Special project, directed reading, and research arranged by an individual graduate student and a faculty member in areas supplementing regular course offerings.
ENG890.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Department of English. Approval of department.

ENG893.name: Interdisciplinary Seminar
ENG893.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
ENG893.description: Examination of a theme, topic, or genre from several different national and disciplinary perspectives in the appropriate cultural and socio-historical context. Significant texts and important critical analysis selected from Great Britain, Spain, France, Germany, the Americas, and others.

ENG896.name: Practicum in English Language and Literature
ENG896.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
ENG896.description: Supervised graduate practicums, observations, or internships in the teaching of English language and literature.
ENG896.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Department of English. Approval of department.

ENG897.name: Seminar in Feminist Theories, Epistemologies, and Pedagogy
ENG897.description: Foundational knowledge, theory, epistemology, and pedagogy in women’s and gender studies from a multi-disciplinary, global perspective.

ENG898.name: Master's Research
ENG898.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
ENG898.description: Directed research in support of Plan B master's degree requirements.
ENG898.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Department of English. Approval of department.

ENG899.name: Master's Thesis Research
ENG899.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
ENG899.description: Directed research leading to a master's thesis, used in partial fulfillment of Plan A master's degree requirements.
ENG899.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Department of English. Approval of department.

ENG990.name: Independent Study
ENG990.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
ENG990.description: Special project, directed reading, and research arranged by an individual doctoral student and a faculty member in areas supplementing the regular course offerings.
ENG990.restrictions: Open only to doctoral students in the English major. Approval of department.

ENG999.name: Doctoral Dissertation Research
ENG999.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
ENG999.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the College of Arts and Letters or in the Department of English or in the English Major.
